fields.name: mqtt
fields.desc: Global MQTT configuration. The configs here work as default values which can be overridden in zone configs

fields.name: zones
fields.desc: A zone is a set of configs grouped by the zone name. For flexible configuration mapping, the name can be set to a listener's zone config. NOTE: A built-in zone named default is auto created and can not be deleted.

fields.name: authentication
fields.desc:
Default authentication configs for all MQTT listeners. For per-listener overrides see authentication in listener configs This option can be configured with:
  • []: The default value, it allows *ALL* logins
  • one: For example {enable:true,backend:"built_in_database",mechanism="password_based"}
  • chain: An array of structs.
When a chain is configured, the login credentials are checked against the backends per the configured order, until an 'allow' or 'deny' decision can be made. If there is no decision after a full chain exhaustion, the login is rejected.

fields.name: authorization
fields.desc:
Authorization a.k.a. ACL.
In EMQX, MQTT client access control is extremely flexible.
An out-of-the-box set of authorization data sources are supported. For example,
'file' source is to support concise and yet generic ACL rules in a file;
'built_in_database' source can be used to store per-client customizable rule sets, natively in the EMQX node;
'http' source to make EMQX call an external HTTP API to make the decision;
'PostgreSQL' etc. to look up clients or rules from external databases

fields.name: broker
fields.desc: Message broker options.

fields.name: sys_topics
fields.desc: System topics configuration.

fields.name: bootstrap_file
fields.desc:
Bootstrap file is used to add an api_key when emqx is launched,
      the format is:
       ```
       7e729ae70d23144b:2QILI9AcQ9BYlVqLDHQNWN2saIjBV4egr1CZneTNKr9CpK
       ec3907f865805db0:Ee3taYltUKtoBVD9C3XjQl9C6NXheip8Z9B69BpUv5JxVHL
       ```

desc: API Key, can be used to request API other than the management API key and the Dashboard user management API

fields.name: path
fields.desc:
Path to the file which contains the ACL rules.
If the file provisioned before starting EMQX node,
it can be placed anywhere as long as EMQX has read access to it.
That is, EMQX will treat it as read only.

In case the rule-set is created or updated from EMQX Dashboard or HTTP API,
a new file will be created and placed in `authz` subdirectory inside EMQX's `data_dir`,
and the old file will not be used anymore.

desc: Authorization using a static file.

fields.name: actions
fields.desc:
The actions triggered when the alarm is activated.
Currently, the following actions are supported: log and publish. log is to write the alarm to log (console or file). publish is to publish the alarm as an MQTT message to the system topics: $SYS/brokers/emqx@xx.xx.xx.x/alarms/activate and $SYS/brokers/emqx@xx.xx.xx.x/alarms/deactivate

fields.name: size_limit
fields.desc:
The maximum total number of deactivated alarms to keep as history.
When this limit is exceeded, the oldest deactivated alarms are deleted to cap the total number.

fields.name: validity_period
fields.desc:
Retention time of deactivated alarms. Alarms are not deleted immediately
when deactivated, but after the retention time.

desc: Settings for the alarms.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable or disable the authorization cache.

fields.name: max_size
fields.desc: Maximum number of cached items.

fields.name: ttl
fields.desc: Time to live for the cached data.

desc: Settings for the authorization cache.

fields.name: enable_session_registry
fields.desc: Enable session registry

fields.name: session_locking_strategy
fields.desc:
Session locking strategy in a cluster.
  - `local`: only lock the session on the current node
  - `one`: select only one remote node to lock the session
  - `quorum`: select some nodes to lock the session
  - `all`: lock the session on all the nodes in the cluster

fields.name: shared_subscription_strategy
fields.desc:
Dispatch strategy for shared subscription.
  - `random`: dispatch the message to a random selected subscriber
  - `round_robin`: select the subscribers in a round-robin manner
  - `round_robin_per_group`: select the subscribers in round-robin fashion within each shared subscriber group
  - `local`: select random local subscriber otherwise select random cluster-wide
  - `sticky`: always use the last selected subscriber to dispatch, until the subscriber disconnects.
  - `hash_clientid`: select the subscribers by hashing the `clientIds`
  - `hash_topic`: select the subscribers by hashing the source topic

fields.name: route_batch_clean
fields.desc: Enable batch clean for deleted routes.

desc: Message broker options.

fields.name: level
fields.desc: Compression level.

fields.name: mem_level
fields.desc:
Specifies the size of the compression state.
Lower values decrease memory usage per connection.

fields.name: strategy
fields.desc: Specifies the compression strategy.

fields.name: server_context_takeover
fields.desc: Takeover means the compression state is retained between server messages.

fields.name: client_context_takeover
fields.desc: Takeover means the compression state is retained between client messages.

fields.name: server_max_window_bits
fields.desc: Specifies the size of the compression context for the server.

fields.name: client_max_window_bits
fields.desc: Specifies the size of the compression context for the client.

desc: Compression options.

fields.name: client_connected
fields.desc: Enable to publish client connected event messages

fields.name: client_disconnected
fields.desc: Enable to publish client disconnected event messages.

fields.name: client_subscribed
fields.desc: Enable to publish event message that client subscribed a topic successfully.

fields.name: client_unsubscribed
fields.desc: Enable to publish event message that client unsubscribed a topic successfully.

desc:
Enable or disable client lifecycle event publishing.

The following options affect MQTT clients as well as
gateway clients. The types of the clients
are distinguished by the topic prefix:

- For the MQTT clients, the format is:
`$SYS/broker/<node>/clients/<clientid>/<event>`
- For the Gateway clients, it is
`$SYS/broker/<node>/gateway/<gateway-name>/clients/<clientid>/<event>`

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable forced garbage collection.

fields.name: count
fields.desc: GC the process after this many received messages.

fields.name: bytes
fields.desc: GC the process after specified number of bytes have passed through.

desc:
Force garbage collection in MQTT connection process after
 they process certain number of messages or bytes of data.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable `force_shutdown` feature.

fields.name: max_message_queue_len
fields.desc: Maximum message queue length.

fields.name: max_heap_size
fields.desc: Total heap size

desc:
When the process message queue length, or the memory bytes
reaches a certain value, the process is forced to close.

Note: "message queue" here refers to the "message mailbox"
of the Erlang process, not the `mqueue` of QoS 1 and QoS 2.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: PEM format private key file.

fields.name: verify
fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.

fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.20.

fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.20.

fields.name: password
fields.desc: String containing the user's password. Only used if the private key file is password-protected.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: PEM format private key file.

fields.name: verify
fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.

fields.name: reuse_sessions
fields.desc: Enable TLS session reuse.

fields.name: depth
fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.

fields.name: password
fields.desc: String containing the user's password. Only used if the private key file is password-protected.

fields.name: versions
fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.

fields.name: ciphers
fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

fields.name: secure_renegotiate
fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.

fields.name: hibernate_after
fields.desc: Hibernate the SSL process after idling for amount of time reducing its memory footprint.

fields.name: dhfile
fields.desc:
Path to a file containing PEM-encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters are used.
NOTE: The dhfile option is not supported by TLS 1.3.

fields.name: fail_if_no_peer_cert
fields.desc:
Used together with {verify, verify_peer} by an TLS/DTLS server.
If set to true, the server fails if the client does not have a
certificate to send, that is, sends an empty certificate.
If set to false, it fails only if the client sends an invalid
certificate (an empty certificate is considered valid).

fields.name: honor_cipher_order
fields.desc:
An important security setting, it forces the cipher to be set based
 on the server-specified order instead of the client-specified order,
 hence enforcing the (usually more properly configured) security
 ordering of the server administrator.

fields.name: client_renegotiation
fields.desc:
In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,
the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.
This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.
The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,
but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.
The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in
long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on
the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.

fields.name: handshake_timeout
fields.desc: Maximum time duration allowed for the handshake to complete

fields.name: gc_after_handshake
fields.desc: Memory usage tuning. If enabled, will immediately perform a garbage collection after the TLS/SSL handshake.

fields.name: enable_crl_check
fields.desc: Whether to enable CRL verification for this listener.

desc: Socket options for SSL connections.

fields.name: depth
fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.

fields.name: password
fields.desc: String containing the user's password. Only used if the private key file is password-protected.

fields.name: versions
fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.

fields.name: ciphers
fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

fields.name: secure_renegotiate
fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.

fields.name: hibernate_after
fields.desc: Hibernate the SSL process after idling for amount of time reducing its memory footprint.

fields.name: dhfile
fields.desc:
Path to a file containing PEM-encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters are used.
NOTE: The dhfile option is not supported by TLS 1.3.

fields.name: fail_if_no_peer_cert
fields.desc:
Used together with {verify, verify_peer} by an TLS/DTLS server.
If set to true, the server fails if the client does not have a
certificate to send, that is, sends an empty certificate.
If set to false, it fails only if the client sends an invalid
certificate (an empty certificate is considered valid).

fields.name: honor_cipher_order
fields.desc:
An important security setting, it forces the cipher to be set based
 on the server-specified order instead of the client-specified order,
 hence enforcing the (usually more properly configured) security
 ordering of the server administrator.

fields.name: client_renegotiation
fields.desc:
In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,
the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.
This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.
The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,
but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.
The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in
long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on
the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.

fields.name: handshake_timeout
fields.desc: Maximum time duration allowed for the handshake to complete

desc: Socket options for WebSocket/SSL connections.

fields.name: tcp
fields.desc: TCP listeners.

fields.name: ssl
fields.desc: SSL listeners.

fields.name: ws
fields.desc: HTTP websocket listeners.

fields.name: wss
fields.desc: HTTPS websocket listeners.

fields.name: quic
fields.desc: QUIC listeners.

desc: MQTT listeners identified by their protocol type and assigned names

fields.name: idle_timeout
fields.desc:
Configure the duration of time that a connection can remain idle (i.e., without any data transfer) before being:
  - Automatically disconnected  if no CONNECT package is received from the client yet.
  - Put into hibernation mode to save resources if some CONNECT packages are already received.
Note: Please set the parameter with caution as long idle time will lead to resource waste.

fields.name: max_packet_size
fields.desc: Maximum MQTT packet size allowed.

fields.name: max_clientid_len
fields.desc: Maximum allowed length of MQTT Client ID.

fields.name: max_topic_levels
fields.desc: Maximum topic levels allowed.

fields.name: max_qos_allowed
fields.desc: Maximum QoS allowed.

fields.name: max_topic_alias
fields.desc: Maximum topic alias, 0 means no topic alias supported.

fields.name: retain_available
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT retained message.

fields.name: wildcard_subscription
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT wildcard subscription.

fields.name: shared_subscription
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT shared subscription.

fields.name: exclusive_subscription
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT exclusive subscription.

fields.name: ignore_loop_deliver
fields.desc: Whether the messages sent by the MQTT v3.1.1/v3.1.0 client will be looped back to the publisher itself, similar to No Local in MQTT 5.0.

fields.name: strict_mode
fields.desc:
Whether to parse MQTT messages in strict mode.
In strict mode, invalid utf8 strings in for example client ID, topic name, etc. will cause the client to be disconnected.

fields.name: response_information
fields.desc: UTF-8 string, for creating the response topic, for example, if set to reqrsp/, the publisher/subscriber will communicate using the topic prefix reqrsp/. To disable this feature, input "" in the text box below. Only applicable to MQTT 5.0 clients.

fields.name: server_keepalive
fields.desc: The keep alive duration required by EMQX. To use the setting from the client side, choose disabled from the drop-down list. Only applicable to MQTT 5.0 clients.

fields.name: keepalive_backoff
fields.desc: The coefficient EMQX uses to confirm whether the keep alive duration of the client expires. Formula: Keep Alive * Backoff * 2

fields.name: max_subscriptions
fields.desc: Maximum number of subscriptions allowed per client.

fields.name: upgrade_qos
fields.desc: Force upgrade of QoS level according to subscription.

fields.name: max_inflight
fields.desc: Maximum number of QoS 1 and QoS 2 messages that are allowed to be delivered simultaneously before completing the acknowledgment.

fields.name: retry_interval
fields.desc: Retry interval for QoS 1/2 message delivering.

fields.name: max_awaiting_rel
fields.desc: For each publisher session, the maximum number of outstanding QoS 2 messages pending on the client to send PUBREL. After reaching this limit, new QoS 2 PUBLISH requests will be rejected with `147(0x93)` until either PUBREL is received or timed out.

fields.name: await_rel_timeout
fields.desc: For client to broker QoS 2 message, the time limit for the broker to wait before the `PUBREL` message is received. The wait is aborted after timed out, meaning the packet ID is freed for new `PUBLISH` requests. Receiving a stale `PUBREL` causes a warning level log. Note, the message is delivered to subscribers before entering the wait for PUBREL.

fields.name: session_expiry_interval
fields.desc: Specifies how long the session will expire after the connection is disconnected, only for non-MQTT 5.0 connections.

fields.name: max_mqueue_len
fields.desc: Maximum queue length. Enqueued messages when persistent client disconnected, or inflight window is full.

fields.name: mqueue_priorities
fields.desc: Topic priorities. Priority number [1-255] There's no priority table by default, hence all messages are treated equal. **NOTE**: Comma and equal signs are not allowed for priority topic names. **NOTE**: Messages for topics not in the priority table are treated as either highest or lowest priority depending on the configured value for mqtt.mqueue_default_priority. **Examples**: To configure "topic/1" > "topic/2": mqueue_priorities: {"topic/1": 10, "topic/2": 8}

fields.name: mqueue_default_priority
fields.desc: Default topic priority, which will be used by topics not in Topic Priorities (mqueue_priorities).

fields.name: mqueue_store_qos0
fields.desc: Specifies whether to store QoS 0 messages in the message queue while the connection is down but the session remains.

fields.name: use_username_as_clientid
fields.desc: Whether to use Username as Client ID. This setting takes effect later than Use Peer Certificate as Username and Use peer certificate as Client ID.

fields.name: peer_cert_as_username
fields.desc: Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Username. Only works for the TLS connection. Supported configurations are the following: - cn: CN field of the certificate - dn: DN field of the certificate - crt: Content of the DER or PEM certificate - pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format and use as Username - md5: MD5 value of the DER or PEM certificate

fields.name: peer_cert_as_clientid
fields.desc: Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Client ID. Only works for the TLS connection. Supported configurations are the following: - cn: CN field of the certificate - dn: DN field of the certificate - crt: DER or PEM certificate - pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format and use as Client ID - md5: MD5 value of the DER or PEM certificate

desc:
Global MQTT configuration.
The configs here work as default values which can be overridden in zone configs

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc: Path to the certificate file. Will be deprecated in 5.1, use .ssl_options.certfile instead.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: Path to the secret key file. Will be deprecated in 5.1, use .ssl_options.keyfile instead.

fields.name: ciphers
fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"
NOTE: QUIC listener supports only 'tlsv1.3' ciphers

fields.name: idle_timeout
fields.desc: How long a connection can go idle before it is gracefully shut down. 0 to disable

fields.name: handshake_idle_timeout
fields.desc: How long a handshake can idle before it is discarded.

fields.name: keep_alive_interval
fields.desc: How often to send PING frames to keep a connection alive. 0 means disabled.

fields.name: ssl_options
fields.desc: TLS options for QUIC transport

fields.name: enabled
fields.desc: Enable listener.

fields.name: bind
fields.desc: IP address and port for the listening socket.

fields.name: acceptors
fields.desc: The size of the listener's receiving pool.

fields.name: max_connections
fields.desc: The maximum number of concurrent connections allowed by the listener.

fields.name: mountpoint
fields.desc:
When publishing or subscribing, prefix all topics with a mountpoint string. The prefixed string will be removed from the topic name when the message is delivered to the subscriber. The mountpoint is a way that users can use to implement isolation of message routing between different listeners. For example if a client A subscribes to `t` with `listeners.tcp.\.mountpoint` set to `some_tenant`, then the client actually subscribes to the topic `some_tenant/t`. Similarly, if another client B (connected to the same listener as the client A) sends a message to topic `t`, the message is routed to all the clients subscribed `some_tenant/t`, so client A will receive the message, with topic name `t`.
Set to `""` to disable the feature.
Variables in mountpoint string: - ${clientid}: clientid - ${username}: username

fields.name: zone
fields.desc: The configuration zone to which the listener belongs.

fields.name: limiter
fields.desc: Type of the rate limit.

fields.name: enable_authn
fields.desc: Set true (default) to enable client authentication on this listener, the authentication process goes through the configured authentication chain. When set to false to allow any clients with or without authentication information such as username or password to log in. When set to quick_deny_anonymous, it behaves like when set to true, but clients will be denied immediately without going through any authenticators if username is not provided. This is useful to fence off anonymous clients early.

desc: Settings for the MQTT over WebSocket/SSL listener.

fields.name: enable_ocsp_stapling
fields.desc: Whether to enable Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) stapling for the listener.  If set to true, requires defining the OCSP responder URL and issuer PEM path.

fields.name: responder_url
fields.desc: URL for the OCSP responder to check the server certificate against.

fields.name: issuer_pem
fields.desc: PEM-encoded certificate of the OCSP issuer for the server certificate.

fields.name: refresh_interval
fields.desc: The period to refresh the OCSP response for the server.

fields.name: refresh_http_timeout
fields.desc: The timeout for the HTTP request when checking OCSP responses.

desc: Per listener OCSP Stapling configuration.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: PEM format private key file.

fields.name: verify
fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.

fields.name: reuse_sessions
fields.desc: Enable TLS session reuse.

fields.name: depth
fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.

fields.name: password
fields.desc: String containing the user's password. Only used if the private key file is password-protected.

fields.name: versions
fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.

fields.desc:

NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.

fields.name: secure_renegotiate
fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.

fields.name: hibernate_after
fields.desc: Hibernate the SSL process after idling for amount of time reducing its memory footprint.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable TLS.

fields.name: server_name_indication
fields.desc:
Specify the host name to be used in TLS Server Name Indication extension.
For instance, when connecting to "server.example.net", the genuine server which accepts the connection and performs TLS handshake may differ from the host the TLS client initially connects to, e.g. when connecting to an IP address or when the host has multiple resolvable DNS records
If not specified, it will default to the host name string which is used to establish the connection, unless it is IP addressed used.
The host name is then also used in the host name verification of the peer certificate.
The special value 'disable' prevents the Server Name Indication extension from being sent and disables the hostname verification check.

desc: Socket options for SSL clients.

fields.name: sys_msg_interval
fields.desc: Time interval of publishing `$SYS` messages.

fields.name: sys_heartbeat_interval
fields.desc:
Time interval for publishing following heartbeat messages:
  - `$SYS/brokers/<node>/uptime`
  - `$SYS/brokers/<node>/datetime`

fields.name: sys_event_messages
fields.desc: Client events messages.

desc:
The EMQX Broker periodically publishes its own status, message statistics,
client online and offline events to the system topic starting with `$SYS/`.

The following options control the behavior of `$SYS` topics.
Features related to system monitoring and introspection.

fields.name: cpu_check_interval
fields.desc: The time interval for the periodic CPU check.

fields.name: cpu_high_watermark
fields.desc:
The threshold, as percentage of system CPU load,
 for how much system cpu can be used before the corresponding alarm is raised.

fields.name: cpu_low_watermark
fields.desc:
The threshold, as percentage of system CPU load,
 for how much system cpu can be used before the corresponding alarm is cleared.

fields.name: mem_check_interval
fields.desc: The time interval for the periodic memory check.

fields.name: sysmem_high_watermark
fields.desc:
The threshold, as percentage of system memory,
 for how much system memory can be allocated before the corresponding alarm is raised.

fields.name: long_gc
fields.desc: When an Erlang process spends long time to perform garbage collection, a warning level long_gc log is emitted, and an MQTT message is published to the system topic $SYS/sysmon/long_gc.

fields.name: long_schedule
fields.desc: When the Erlang VM detect a task scheduled for too long, a warning level 'long_schedule' log is emitted, and an MQTT message is published to the system topic $SYS/sysmon/long_schedule.

fields.name: large_heap
fields.desc: When an Erlang process consumed a large amount of memory for its heap space, the system will write a warning level large_heap log, and an MQTT message is published to the system topic $SYS/sysmon/large_heap.

fields.name: busy_dist_port
fields.desc: When the RPC connection used to communicate with other nodes in the cluster is overloaded, there will be a busy_dist_port warning log, and an MQTT message is published to system topic $SYS/sysmon/busy_dist_port.

fields.name: busy_port
fields.desc: When a port (e.g. TCP socket) is overloaded, there will be a busy_port warning log, and an MQTT message is published to the system topic $SYS/sysmon/busy_port.

desc: WebSocket listener options.

A `Zone` defines a set of configuration items (such as the maximum number of connections) that can be shared between multiple listeners. `Listener` can refer to a `Zone` through the configuration item listener.\.\.zone. The configs defined in the zones will override the global configs with the same key. For example, given the following config: ``` a { b: 1, c: 1 } zone.my_zone { a { b:2 } } ``` The global config `a` is overridden by the configs `a` inside the zone `my_zone`. If there is a listener using the zone `my_zone`, the value of config `a` will be: `{b:2, c: 1}`. Note that although the default value of `a.c` is `0`, the global value is used, i.e. configs in the zone have no default values. To override `a.c` one must configure it explicitly in the zone. All the global configs that can be overridden in zones are: - `stats.*` - `mqtt.*` - `authorization.*` - `flapping_detect.*` - `force_shutdown.*` - `conn_congestion.*` - `force_gc.*`

fields.name: listeners

HTTP(s) listeners are identified by their protocol type and are

Listeners must have a unique combination of port number and IP address.
For example, an HTTP listener can listen on all configured IP addresses
on a given port for a machine by specifying the IP address 0.0.0.0.
Alternatively, the HTTP listener can specify a unique IP address for each listener,
but use the same port.

Support Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).
Allows a server to indicate any origins (domain, scheme, or port) other than
its own from which a browser should permit loading resources.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc: PEM format private key file.

fields.name: verify
fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.

fields.name: reuse_sessions
fields.desc: Enable TLS session reuse.

fields.name: depth
fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.

fields.name: versions
fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.

fields.name: ciphers
fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"

fields.name: secure_renegotiate
fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.

fields.name: hibernate_after
fields.desc: Hibernate the SSL process after idling for amount of time reducing its memory footprint.

fields.name: dhfile
fields.desc:
Path to a file containing PEM-encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters are used.
NOTE: The dhfile option is not supported by TLS 1.3.

fields.name: honor_cipher_order
fields.desc:
An important security setting, it forces the cipher to be set based
 on the server-specified order instead of the client-specified order,
 hence enforcing the (usually more properly configured) security
 ordering of the server administrator.

fields.name: client_renegotiation
fields.desc:
In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,
the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.
This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.
The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,
but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.
The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in
long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on
the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.

fields.name: handshake_timeout
fields.desc: Maximum time duration allowed for the handshake to complete

fields.name: server_name_indication

Specify the host name to be used in TLS Server Name Indication extension.
For instance, when connecting to "server.example.net", the genuine server which accepts the connection and performs TLS handshake may differ from the host the TLS client initially connects to, e.g. when connecting to an IP address or when the host has multiple resolvable DNS records
If not specified, it will default to the host name string which is used to establish the connection, unless it is IP addressed used.
The host name is then also used in the host name verification of the peer certificate.
The special value 'disable' prevents the Server Name Indication extension from being sent and disables the hostname verification check.

fields.name: user_properties
fields.desc: From which variable should the MQTT message's User-Property pairs be taken from. The value must be a map. You may configure it to ${pub_props.'User-Property'} or use SELECT *,pub_props.'User-Property' as user_properties to forward the original user properties to the republished message. You may also call map_put function like map_put('my-prop-name', 'my-prop-value', user_properties) as user_properties to inject user properties. NOTE: MQTT spec allows duplicated user property names, but EMQX Rule-Engine does not.

desc: The arguments of the built-in 'republish' action.One can use variables in the args. The variables are selected by the rule. For example, if the rule SQL is defined as following: SELECT clientid, qos, payload FROM "t/1" Then there are 3 variables available: clientid, qos and payload. And if we've set the args to: { topic = "t/${clientid}" qos = "${qos}" payload = "msg: ${payload}" } When the rule is triggered by an MQTT message with payload = `hello`, qos = 1, clientid = `Steve`, the rule will republish a new MQTT message to topic `t/Steve`, payload = `msg: hello`, and `qos = 1`.

fields.name: ignore_sys_message

fields.name: actions
fields.desc:
A list of actions of the rule.
An action can be a string that refers to the channel ID of an EMQX bridge, or an object
that refers to a function.
There a some built-in functions like "republish" and "console", and we also support user
provided functions in the format: "{module}:{function}".
The actions in the list are executed sequentially.
This means that if one of the action is executing slowly, all the following actions will not
be executed until it returns.
If one of the action crashed, all other actions come after it will still be executed, in the
original order.
If there's any error when running an action, there will be an error message, and the 'failure'
counter of the function action or the bridge channel will increase.

fields.desc: Enable or disable the rule

fields.name: description
fields.desc: The description of the rule

fields.name: metadata
fields.desc: Rule metadata, do not change manually

To write your own function, checkout the function console and republish in the source file: apps/emqx_rule_engine/src/emqx_rule_actions.erl as an example.

fields.name: args
fields.desc: The args will be passed as the 3rd argument to module:function/3, checkout the function console and republish in the source file: apps/emqx_rule_engine/src/emqx_rule_actions.erl as an example.

fields.name: no_match
fields.desc:
Default access control action if the user or client matches no ACL rules,
or if no such user or client is found by the configurable authorization
sources such as built_in_database, an HTTP API, or a query against PostgreSQL.
Find more details in 'authorization.sources' config.

fields.name: deny_action
fields.desc: The action when the authorization check rejects an operation.

fields.name: sources
fields.desc:
Authorization data sources.
An array of authorization (ACL) data providers. It is designed as an array, not a hash-map, so the sources can be ordered to form a chain of access controls.
When authorizing a 'publish' or 'subscribe' action, the configured sources are checked in order. When checking an ACL source, in case the client (identified by username or client ID) is not found, it moves on to the next source. And it stops immediately once an 'allow' or 'deny' decision is returned.
If the client is not found in any of the sources, the default action configured in 'authorization.no_match' is applied.
NOTE: The source elements are identified by their 'type'. It is NOT allowed to configure two or more sources of the same type.

desc: Settings that control client authorization.

fields.name: name

fields.name: discovery_strategy
fields.desc:
Service discovery method for the cluster nodes. Possible values are: - manual: Use emqx ctl cluster command to manage cluster.
- static: Configure static nodes list by setting seeds in config file.
- dns: Use DNS A record to discover peer nodes.
- etcd: Use etcd to discover peer nodes.
- k8s: Use Kubernetes API to discover peer pods.

fields.name: core_nodes
fields.desc:
List of core nodes that the replicant will connect to.
Note: this parameter only takes effect when the backend is set to rlog and the role is set to replicant.
This value needs to be defined for manual or static cluster discovery mechanisms.
If an automatic cluster discovery mechanism is being used (such as etcd), there is no need to set this value.

fields.name: autoclean
fields.desc: Remove disconnected nodes from the cluster after this interval.

fields.name: autoheal
fields.desc: If true, the node will try to heal network partitions automatically.

fields.name: proto_dist
fields.desc:
The Erlang distribution protocol for the cluster.
- inet_tcp: IPv4 TCP
- inet_tls: IPv4 TLS, works together with etc/ssl_dist.conf

desc:
EMQX nodes can form a cluster to scale up the total capacity.
Here holds the configs to instruct how individual nodes can discover each other.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable this log handler.

fields.name: level
fields.desc:
The log level for the current log handler.
Defaults to warning.

fields.name: time_offset
fields.desc: The time offset to be used when formatting the timestamp. Can be one of: - system: the time offset used by the local system - utc: the UTC time offset - +-[hh]:[mm]: user specified time offset, such as "-02:00" or "+00:00" Defaults to: system.

fields.name: chars_limit
fields.desc:
Set the maximum length of a single log message. If this length is exceeded, the log message will be truncated.
NOTE: Restrict char limiter if formatter is JSON , it will get a truncated incomplete JSON data, which is not recommended.

fields.name: formatter
fields.desc: Choose log formatter. text for free text, and json for structured logging.

fields.name: single_line
fields.desc: Print logs in a single line if set to true. Otherwise, log messages may span multiple lines.

fields.name: sync_mode_qlen
fields.desc:
As long as the number of buffered log events is lower than this value,
all log events are handled asynchronously. This means that the client process sending the log event,
by calling a log function in the Logger API, does not wait for a response from the handler
but continues executing immediately after the event is sent.
It is not affected by the time it takes the handler to print the event to the log device.
If the message queue grows larger than this value,
the handler starts handling log events synchronously instead,
meaning that the client process sending the event must wait for a response.
When the handler reduces the message queue to a level below the sync_mode_qlen threshold,
asynchronous operation is resumed.

fields.name: drop_mode_qlen
fields.desc:
When the number of buffered log events is larger than this value, the new log events are dropped.
When drop mode is activated or deactivated, a message is printed in the logs.

fields.name: flush_qlen
fields.desc:
If the number of buffered log events grows larger than this threshold, a flush (delete) operation takes place.
To flush events, the handler discards the buffered log messages without logging.

fields.name: supervisor_reports
fields.desc:
Type of supervisor reports that are logged. Defaults to error
- error: only log errors in the Erlang processes
. - progress: log process startup.

fields.name: max_depth
fields.desc: Maximum depth for Erlang term log formatting and Erlang process message queue inspection.

desc: Log handler that prints log events to the EMQX console.

fields.name: file_handlers
fields.desc: File-based log handlers.

desc:
EMQX logging supports multiple sinks for the log events.
Each sink is represented by a _log handler_, which can be configured independently.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable log burst control feature.

fields.name: max_count
fields.desc: Maximum number of log events to handle within a `window_time` interval. After the limit is reached, successive events are dropped until the end of the `window_time`.

fields.name: window_time
fields.desc: See max_count.

desc:
Large bursts of log events produced in a short time can potentially cause problems, such as:
 - Log files grow very large
 - Log files are rotated too quickly, and useful information gets overwritten
 - Overall performance impact on the system

Log burst limit feature can temporarily disable logging to avoid these issues.

fields.name: file
fields.desc: Name the log file.

fields.name: max_size
fields.desc: This parameter controls log file rotation. The value `infinity` means the log file will grow indefinitely, otherwise the log file will be rotated once it reaches `max_size` in bytes.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable this log handler.

fields.name: level
fields.desc:
The log level for the current log handler.
Defaults to warning.

fields.name: time_offset
fields.desc: The time offset to be used when formatting the timestamp. Can be one of: - system: the time offset used by the local system - utc: the UTC time offset - +-[hh]:[mm]: user specified time offset, such as "-02:00" or "+00:00" Defaults to: system.

fields.name: chars_limit
fields.desc:
Set the maximum length of a single log message. If this length is exceeded, the log message will be truncated.
NOTE: Restrict char limiter if formatter is JSON , it will get a truncated incomplete JSON data, which is not recommended.

fields.name: formatter
fields.desc: Choose log formatter. text for free text, and json for structured logging.

fields.name: single_line
fields.desc: Print logs in a single line if set to true. Otherwise, log messages may span multiple lines.

fields.name: sync_mode_qlen
fields.desc:
As long as the number of buffered log events is lower than this value,
all log events are handled asynchronously. This means that the client process sending the log event,
by calling a log function in the Logger API, does not wait for a response from the handler
but continues executing immediately after the event is sent.
It is not affected by the time it takes the handler to print the event to the log device.
If the message queue grows larger than this value,
the handler starts handling log events synchronously instead,
meaning that the client process sending the event must wait for a response.
When the handler reduces the message queue to a level below the sync_mode_qlen threshold,
asynchronous operation is resumed.

fields.name: drop_mode_qlen
fields.desc:
When the number of buffered log events is larger than this value, the new log events are dropped.
When drop mode is activated or deactivated, a message is printed in the logs.

fields.name: flush_qlen
fields.desc:
If the number of buffered log events grows larger than this threshold, a flush (delete) operation takes place.
To flush events, the handler discards the buffered log messages without logging.

fields.name: supervisor_reports
fields.desc:
Type of supervisor reports that are logged. Defaults to error
- error: only log errors in the Erlang processes
. - progress: log process startup.

fields.name: max_depth
fields.desc: Maximum depth for Erlang term log formatting and Erlang process message queue inspection.

desc: Log handler that prints log events to files.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable log handler overload kill feature.

fields.name: mem_size
fields.desc: Maximum memory size that the log handler process is allowed to use.

fields.name: qlen
fields.desc: Maximum allowed queue length.

fields.name: restart_after
fields.desc: The handler restarts automatically after a delay in the event of termination, unless the value `infinity` is set, which blocks any subsequent restarts.

desc:
Log overload kill features an overload protection that activates when the log handlers use too much memory or have too many buffered log messages.
When the overload is detected, the log handler is terminated and restarted after a cooldown period.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable log rotation feature.

fields.name: count
fields.desc: Maximum number of log files.

desc:
By default, the logs are stored in `./log` directory (for installation from zip file) or in `/var/log/emqx` (for binary installation).
This section of the configuration controls the number of files kept for each log handler.

fields.name: name
fields.desc: Unique name of the EMQX node. It must follow %name%@FQDN or %name%@IPv4 format.

fields.name: cookie
fields.desc:
Secret cookie is a random string that should be the same on all nodes in
the given EMQX cluster, but unique per EMQX cluster. It is used to prevent EMQX nodes that
belong to different clusters from accidentally connecting to each other.

fields.name: process_limit
fields.desc:
Maximum number of simultaneously existing processes for this Erlang system.
The actual maximum chosen may be much larger than the Number passed.
For more information, see: https://www.erlang.org/doc/man/erl.html

fields.name: max_ports
fields.desc:
Maximum number of simultaneously existing ports for this Erlang system.
The actual maximum chosen may be much larger than the Number passed.
For more information, see: https://www.erlang.org/doc/man/erl.html

fields.name: dist_buffer_size
fields.desc: Erlang's distribution buffer busy limit in kilobytes.

fields.name: global_gc_interval
fields.desc: Periodic garbage collection interval. Set to disabled to have it disabled.

fields.name: role
fields.desc:
Select a node role.
core nodes provide durability of the data, and take care of writes. It is recommended to place core nodes in different racks or different availability zones.
replicant nodes are ephemeral worker nodes. Removing them from the cluster doesn't affect database redundancy
It is recommended to have more replicant nodes than core nodes.
Note: this parameter only takes effect when the backend is set to rlog.

desc: Node name, cookie, config & data directories and the Erlang virtual machine (BEAM) boot parameters.

fields.name: mode
fields.desc: In sync mode the sending side waits for the ack from the receiving side.

fields.name: driver
fields.desc: Transport protocol used for inter-broker communication

fields.name: async_batch_size
fields.desc:
The maximum number of batch messages sent in asynchronous mode.
      Note that this configuration does not work in synchronous mode.

fields.name: port_discovery
fields.desc:
manual: discover ports by tcp_server_port.
stateless: discover ports in a stateless manner, using the following algorithm. If node name is emqxN@127.0.0.1, where the N is an integer, then the listening port will be 5370 + N.

fields.name: tcp_server_port
fields.desc:
Listening port used by RPC local service.
Note that this config only takes effect when rpc.port_discovery is set to manual.

fields.name: ssl_server_port
fields.desc:
Listening port used by RPC local service.
Note that this config only takes effect when rpc.port_discovery is set to manual and driver is set to ssl.

fields.name: tcp_client_num
fields.desc: Set the maximum number of RPC communication channels initiated by this node to each remote node.

fields.name: connect_timeout
fields.desc: Timeout for establishing an RPC connection.

fields.name: certfile
fields.desc: Path to TLS certificate file used to validate identity of the cluster nodes. Note that this config only takes effect when rpc.driver is set to ssl.

fields.name: keyfile
fields.desc:
Path to the private key file for the rpc.certfile.
Note: contents of this file are secret, so it's necessary to set permissions to 600.

fields.name: cacertfile
fields.desc:
Path to certification authority TLS certificate file used to validate rpc.certfile.
Note: certificates of all nodes in the cluster must be signed by the same CA.

fields.name: send_timeout
fields.desc: Timeout for sending the RPC request.

fields.name: authentication_timeout
fields.desc: Timeout for the remote node authentication.

fields.name: call_receive_timeout
fields.desc: Timeout for the reply to a synchronous RPC.

fields.name: socket_keepalive_idle
fields.desc: How long the connections between the brokers should remain open after the last message is sent.

fields.name: socket_keepalive_interval
fields.desc: The interval between keepalive messages.

fields.name: socket_keepalive_count
fields.desc:
How many times the keepalive probe message can fail to receive a reply
until the RPC connection is considered lost.

fields.name: socket_sndbuf
fields.desc: TCP tuning parameters. TCP sending buffer size.

fields.name: socket_recbuf
fields.desc: TCP tuning parameters. TCP receiving buffer size.

fields.name: socket_buffer
fields.desc: TCP tuning parameters. Socket buffer size in user mode.

fields.name: insecure_fallback
fields.desc: Enable compatibility with old RPC authentication.

desc:
EMQX uses a library called gen_rpc for inter-broker communication.
Most of the time the default config should work, but in case you need to do performance fine-tuning or experiment a bit, this is where to look.

fields.name: pool_size
fields.desc: Size of the connection pool towards the bridge target service.

fields.name: max_overflow
fields.desc: Max Overflow.

fields.name: overflow_ttl
fields.desc: Period of time before workers that exceed the configured pool size ("overflow") to be terminated.

fields.name: overflow_check_period
fields.desc: Period for checking if there are more workers than configured ("overflow").

fields.name: local_threshold_ms
fields.desc: The size of the latency window for selecting among multiple suitable MongoDB instances.

fields.name: connect_timeout_ms
fields.desc: The duration to attempt a connection before timing out.

fields.name: socket_timeout_ms
fields.desc: The duration to attempt to send or to receive on a socket before the attempt times out.

fields.name: server_selection_timeout_ms
fields.desc: Specifies how long to block for server selection before throwing an exception.

fields.name: wait_queue_timeout_ms
fields.desc: The maximum duration that a worker can wait for a connection to become available.

fields.name: heartbeat_frequency_ms
fields.desc: Controls when the driver checks the state of the MongoDB deployment. Specify the interval between checks, counted from the end of the previous check until the beginning of the next one. If the number of connections is increased (which will happen, for example, if you increase the pool size), you may need to increase this period as well to avoid creating too many log entries in the MongoDB log file.

fields.name: min_heartbeat_frequency_ms
fields.desc: Controls the minimum amount of time to wait between heartbeats.

desc: Topology of MongoDB.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable forced garbage collection.

fields.name: count
fields.desc: GC the process after this many received messages.

fields.name: bytes
fields.desc: GC the process after specified number of bytes have passed through.

desc:
Force garbage collection in MQTT connection process after
 they process certain number of messages or bytes of data.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable `force_shutdown` feature.

fields.name: max_message_queue_len
fields.desc: Maximum message queue length.

fields.name: max_heap_size
fields.desc: Total heap size

desc:
When the process message queue length, or the memory bytes
reaches a certain value, the process is forced to close.

Note: "message queue" here refers to the "message mailbox"
of the Erlang process, not the `mqueue` of QoS 1 and QoS 2.

fields.name: idle_timeout
fields.desc:
Configure the duration of time that a connection can remain idle (i.e., without any data transfer) before being:
  - Automatically disconnected  if no CONNECT package is received from the client yet.
  - Put into hibernation mode to save resources if some CONNECT packages are already received.
Note: Please set the parameter with caution as long idle time will lead to resource waste.

fields.name: max_packet_size
fields.desc: Maximum MQTT packet size allowed.

fields.name: max_clientid_len
fields.desc: Maximum allowed length of MQTT Client ID.

fields.name: max_topic_levels
fields.desc: Maximum topic levels allowed.

fields.name: max_qos_allowed
fields.desc: Maximum QoS allowed.

fields.name: max_topic_alias
fields.desc: Maximum topic alias, 0 means no topic alias supported.

fields.name: retain_available
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT retained message.

fields.name: wildcard_subscription
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT wildcard subscription.

fields.name: shared_subscription
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT shared subscription.

fields.name: exclusive_subscription
fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT exclusive subscription.

fields.name: ignore_loop_deliver
fields.desc: Whether the messages sent by the MQTT v3.1.1/v3.1.0 client will be looped back to the publisher itself, similar to No Local in MQTT 5.0.

fields.name: strict_mode
fields.desc:
Whether to parse MQTT messages in strict mode.
In strict mode, invalid utf8 strings in for example client ID, topic name, etc. will cause the client to be disconnected.

fields.name: response_information
fields.desc: UTF-8 string, for creating the response topic, for example, if set to reqrsp/, the publisher/subscriber will communicate using the topic prefix reqrsp/. To disable this feature, input "" in the text box below. Only applicable to MQTT 5.0 clients.

fields.name: server_keepalive
fields.desc: The keep alive duration required by EMQX. To use the setting from the client side, choose disabled from the drop-down list. Only applicable to MQTT 5.0 clients.

fields.name: keepalive_backoff
fields.desc: The coefficient EMQX uses to confirm whether the keep alive duration of the client expires. Formula: Keep Alive * Backoff * 2

fields.name: max_subscriptions
fields.desc: Maximum number of subscriptions allowed per client.

fields.name: upgrade_qos
fields.desc: Force upgrade of QoS level according to subscription.

fields.name: max_inflight
fields.desc: Maximum number of QoS 1 and QoS 2 messages that are allowed to be delivered simultaneously before completing the acknowledgment.

fields.name: retry_interval
fields.desc: Retry interval for QoS 1/2 message delivering.

fields.name: max_awaiting_rel
fields.desc: For each publisher session, the maximum number of outstanding QoS 2 messages pending on the client to send PUBREL. After reaching this limit, new QoS 2 PUBLISH requests will be rejected with `147(0x93)` until either PUBREL is received or timed out.

fields.name: await_rel_timeout
fields.desc: For client to broker QoS 2 message, the time limit for the broker to wait before the `PUBREL` message is received. The wait is aborted after timed out, meaning the packet ID is freed for new `PUBLISH` requests. Receiving a stale `PUBREL` causes a warning level log. Note, the message is delivered to subscribers before entering the wait for PUBREL.

fields.name: session_expiry_interval
fields.desc: Specifies how long the session will expire after the connection is disconnected, only for non-MQTT 5.0 connections.

fields.name: max_mqueue_len
fields.desc: Maximum queue length. Enqueued messages when persistent client disconnected, or inflight window is full.

fields.name: mqueue_priorities
fields.desc: Topic priorities. Priority number [1-255] There's no priority table by default, hence all messages are treated equal. **NOTE**: Comma and equal signs are not allowed for priority topic names. **NOTE**: Messages for topics not in the priority table are treated as either highest or lowest priority depending on the configured value for mqtt.mqueue_default_priority. **Examples**: To configure "topic/1" > "topic/2": mqueue_priorities: {"topic/1": 10, "topic/2": 8}

fields.name: mqueue_default_priority
fields.desc: Default topic priority, which will be used by topics not in Topic Priorities (mqueue_priorities).

fields.name: mqueue_store_qos0
fields.desc: Specifies whether to store QoS 0 messages in the message queue while the connection is down but the session remains.

fields.name: use_username_as_clientid
fields.desc: Whether to use Username as Client ID. This setting takes effect later than Use Peer Certificate as Username and Use peer certificate as Client ID.

fields.name: peer_cert_as_username
fields.desc: Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Username. Only works for the TLS connection. Supported configurations are the following: - cn: CN field of the certificate - dn: DN field of the certificate - crt: Content of the DER or PEM certificate - pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format and use as Username - md5: MD5 value of the DER or PEM certificate

fields.name: peer_cert_as_clientid
fields.desc: Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Client ID. Only works for the TLS connection. Supported configurations are the following: - cn: CN field of the certificate - dn: DN field of the certificate - crt: DER or PEM certificate - pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format and use as Client ID - md5: MD5 value of the DER or PEM certificate

desc:
Global MQTT configuration.
The configs here work as default values which can be overridden in zone configs

fields.desc: URL of the HTTP server.

fields.desc: HTTP request body.

fields.name: enable_pipelining
fields.desc: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.

fields.name: max_retries
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.4.

fields.name: pool_size
fields.desc: The pool size.

fields.name: request
fields.desc: Configure HTTP request parameters.

fields.name: retry_interval
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.4.

fields.name: ssl

fields.name: algorithm
fields.desc: JWT signing algorithm, Supports HMAC (configured as hmac-based) and RSA, ECDSA (configured as public-key).

fields.name: secret
fields.desc: The key to verify the JWT using HMAC algorithm.

fields.name: secret_base64_encoded
fields.desc: Whether secret is base64 encoded.

fields.name: mechanism
fields.desc: Authentication mechanism.

fields.name: acl_claim_name
fields.desc: JWT claim name to use for getting ACL rules.

fields.name: verify_claims
fields.desc: A list of custom claims to validate, which is a list of name/value pairs. Values can use the following placeholders: - ${username}: Will be replaced at runtime with Username used by the client when connecting - ${clientid}: Will be replaced at runtime with Client ID used by the client when connecting Authentication will verify that the value of claims in the JWT (taken from the Password field) matches what is required in verify_claims.

fields.name: from
fields.desc: Field to take JWT from.

fields.desc: Whether to use JWKS.

fields.name: endpoint
fields.desc: JWKS endpoint, it's a read-only endpoint that returns the server's public key set in the JWKS format.

fields.name: pool_size
fields.desc: Size of the connection pool towards the bridge target service.

fields.name: refresh_interval
fields.desc: JWKS refresh interval.

fields.name: from

fields.name: filter

Filter supports the following placeholders: - ${username}: Will be replaced at runtime with Username used by the client when connecting - ${clientid}: Will be replaced at runtime with Client ID used by the client when connecting

fields.name: password_hash_field
fields.desc: Document field that contains password hash.

fields.name: salt_field

fields.name: is_superuser_field

fields.name: password_hash_algorithm

fields.name: mongo_type
fields.desc: Replica set. Must be set to 'rs' when MongoDB server is running in 'replica set' mode.

fields.name: servers
fields.desc:
A Node list for Cluster to connect to. The nodes should be separated with commas, such as: `Node[,Node].`
For each Node should be: The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The MongoDB default port 27017 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

fields.name: w_mode
fields.desc: Write mode.

fields.name: r_mode
fields.desc: Read mode.

fields.name: replica_set_name

fields.name: srv_record

fields.name: pool_size

fields.name: username

fields.name: password

fields.name: chunk_size
fields.desc: The size of each chunk used to import to the built-in database from PSK file

desc: PSK stands for 'Pre-Shared Keys'. This config to enable TLS-PSK authentication. Important! Make sure the SSL listener with only tlsv1.2 enabled, and also PSK cipher suites configured, such as RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384. See listener SSL options config for more details. The IDs and secrets can be provided from a file which is configurable by the init_file field.

fields.name: webhook
fields.desc: WebHook to an HTTP server.

fields.name: mqtt
fields.desc: MQTT bridges to/from another MQTT broker

desc: Configuration for MQTT bridges.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable or disable this bridge

fields.name: resource_opts
fields.desc: Resource options.

fields.name: mode
fields.desc:
The mode of the MQTT Bridge.
- cluster_shareload: create an MQTT connection on each node in the emqx cluster.
In 'cluster_shareload' mode, the incoming load from the remote broker is shared by using shared subscription.
Note that the 'clientid' is suffixed by the node name, this is to avoid clientid conflicts between different nodes. And we can only use shared subscription topic filters for remote.topic of ingress connections.

fields.name: server
fields.desc: The host and port of the remote MQTT broker

fields.name: clientid_prefix
fields.desc: Optional prefix to prepend to the clientid used by egress bridges.

fields.name: reconnect_interval
fields.desc: Deprecated since v5.0.16.

fields.name: proto_ver
fields.desc: The MQTT protocol version

fields.name: bridge_mode
fields.desc:
If enable bridge mode.
NOTE: This setting is only for MQTT protocol version older than 5.0, and the remote MQTT
broker MUST support this feature.
If bridge_mode is set to true, the bridge will indicate to the remote broker that it is a bridge not an ordinary client.
This means that loop detection will be more effective and that retained messages will be propagated correctly.

fields.name: username
fields.desc: The username of the MQTT protocol

fields.name: password
fields.desc: The password of the MQTT protocol

fields.name: clean_start
fields.desc: Whether to start a clean session when reconnecting a remote broker for ingress bridge

fields.name: keepalive
fields.desc:
MQTT Keepalive. Time interval is a string that contains a number followed by time unit:
- `ms` for milliseconds, - `s` for seconds, - `m` for minutes, - `h` for hours;
or combination of whereof: `1h5m0s`

fields.name: retry_interval
fields.desc:
Message retry interval. Delay for the MQTT bridge to retry sending the QoS1/QoS2 messages in case of ACK not received. Time interval is a string that contains a number followed by time unit:
- `ms` for milliseconds, - `s` for seconds, - `m` for minutes, - `h` for hours;
or combination of whereof: `1h5m0s`

fields.name: max_inflight
fields.desc: Max inflight (sent, but un-acked) messages of the MQTT protocol

fields.name: ssl
fields.desc: SSL connection settings.

fields.name: ingress
fields.desc:
The ingress config defines how this bridge receive messages from the remote MQTT broker, and then send them to the local broker.
Template with variables is allowed in 'remote.qos', 'local.topic', 'local.qos', 'local.retain', 'local.payload'.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the input of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then messages got from the remote broker will be sent to both the 'local.topic' and the rule.

fields.name: egress
fields.desc:
The egress config defines how this bridge forwards messages from the local broker to the remote broker.
Template with variables is allowed in 'remote.topic', 'local.qos', 'local.retain', 'local.payload'.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the action of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then both the data got from the rule and the MQTT messages that matches 'local.topic' will be forwarded.

desc: The config for MQTT Bridges.

fields.name: worker_pool_size
fields.desc:
The number of buffer workers. Only applicable for egress type bridges.
For bridges only have ingress direction data flow, it can be set to 0 otherwise must be greater than 0.

fields.name: health_check_interval
fields.desc: Health check interval.

fields.name: start_after_created
fields.desc: Whether start the resource right after created.

fields.name: start_timeout
fields.desc: Time interval to wait for an auto-started resource to become healthy before responding resource creation requests.

fields.name: auto_restart_interval
fields.desc: The auto restart interval after the resource is disconnected.

fields.name: query_mode
fields.desc: Query mode. Optional 'sync/async', default 'async'.

fields.name: request_timeout
fields.desc: Starting from the moment when the request enters the buffer, if the request remains in the buffer for the specified time or is sent but does not receive a response or acknowledgement in time, the request is considered expired.

fields.name: inflight_window
fields.desc: Query inflight window. When query_mode is set to async, this config has to be set to 1 if messages from the same MQTT client have to be strictly ordered.

fields.name: enable_queue
fields.desc: Deprecated since v5.0.14.

fields.name: max_buffer_bytes
fields.desc: Maximum number of bytes to buffer for each buffer worker.

desc: Creation options.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable or disable this bridge

fields.name: resource_opts
fields.desc: Resource options.

fields.name: connect_timeout
fields.desc: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.

fields.name: retry_interval
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.4.

fields.name: pool_type
fields.desc: The type of the pool. Can be one of `random`, `hash`.

fields.name: pool_size
fields.desc: The pool size.

fields.name: enable_pipelining
fields.desc: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.

fields.name: request
fields.desc: Configure HTTP request parameters.

fields.name: ssl
fields.desc: SSL connection settings.

fields.name: url
fields.desc:
The URL of the HTTP Bridge.
Template with variables is allowed in the path, but variables cannot be used in the scheme, host, or port part.
For example, http://localhost:9901/${topic} is allowed, but http://${host}:9901/message or http://localhost:${port}/message is not allowed.

fields.name: direction
fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.12.

fields.name: local_topic
fields.desc:
The MQTT topic filter to be forwarded to the HTTP server. All MQTT 'PUBLISH' messages with the topic matching the local_topic will be forwarded.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the action of a rule (EMQX rule engine), and also local_topic is configured, then both the data got from the rule and the MQTT messages that match local_topic will be forwarded.

fields.name: method
fields.desc:
The method of the HTTP request. All the available methods are: post, put, get, delete.
Template with variables is allowed.

fields.name: headers
fields.desc:
The headers of the HTTP request.
Template with variables is allowed.

fields.name: body
fields.desc:
The body of the HTTP request.
If not provided, the body will be a JSON object of all the available fields.
There, 'all the available fields' means the context of a MQTT message when this webhook is triggered by receiving a MQTT message (the `local_topic` is set), or the context of the event when this webhook is triggered by a rule (i.e. this webhook is used as an action of a rule).
Template with variables is allowed.

fields.name: max_retries
fields.desc: HTTP request max retry times if failed.

fields.name: request_timeout
fields.desc: HTTP request timeout.

The plugins are started in the defined order

fields.name: install_dir
fields.desc:
The installation directory for the external plugins. The plugin beam files and configuration files should reside in the subdirectory named as emqx_foo_bar-0.1.0.
NOTE: For security reasons, this directory should **NOT** be writable by anyone except emqx (or any user which runs EMQX).

desc:
Manage EMQX plugins.
Plugins can be pre-built as a part of EMQX package, or installed as a standalone package in a location specified by install_dir config key
The standalone-installed plugins are referred to as 'external' plugins.

fields.name: name_vsn
fields.desc:
The {name}-{version} of the plugin.
It should match the plugin application name-version as the for the plugin release package name
For example: my_plugin-0.1.0.

fields.name: interval

fields.name: headers
fields.desc:
A list of HTTP Headers when pushing to Push Gateway.
For example, { Authorization = "some-authz-tokens"}

fields.name: job_name
fields.desc:
Job Name that is pushed to the Push Gateway. Available variables:
- ${name}: Name of EMQX node.
- ${host}: Host name of EMQX node.
For example, when the EMQX node name is emqx@127.0.0.1 then the name variable takes value emqx and the host variable takes value 127.0.0.1.
Default value is: ${name}/instance/${name}~${host}

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Turn Prometheus data pushing on or off

desc: Settings for reporting metrics to Prometheus

fields.name: type
fields.desc: Backend type.

fields.name: storage_type
fields.desc: Specifies whether the messages are stored in RAM or persisted on disc.

fields.name: max_retained_messages
fields.desc: Maximum number of retained messages. 0 means no limit.

fields.name: index_specs
fields.desc:
Retainer index specifications: list of arrays of positive ascending integers. Each array specifies an index. Numbers in an index specification are 1-based word positions in topics. Words from specified positions will be used for indexing.
For example, it is good to have [2, 4] index to optimize +/X/+/Y/... topic wildcard subscriptions.

desc: Configuration of the internal database storing retained messages.

fields.name: enable
fields.desc: Enable retainer feature

fields.name: msg_expiry_interval
fields.desc: Message retention time. 0 means message will never be expired.

fields.name: msg_clear_interval
fields.desc:
Periodic interval for cleaning up expired messages.
Never clear if the value is 0.

fields.name: max_payload_size
fields.desc: Maximum retained message size.

fields.name: stop_publish_clear_msg
fields.desc:
When the retained flag of the `PUBLISH` message is set and Payload is empty,
whether to continue to publish the message.
See:
http://docs.oasis-open.org/mqtt/mqtt/v3.1.1/os/mqtt-v3.1.1-os.html#_Toc398718038

fields.name: backend
fields.desc: Settings for the database storing the retained messages.

desc: Configuration related to handling `PUBLISH` packets with a `retain` flag set to 1.
